March 18-20th, 1984:
A severe winter storm brought heavy snow & a thick coat of ice to parts of the Central Plains. Up to 20" of snow fell in parts of Colorado, Nebraska, and Kansas, while 1-2" ice accumulations caused extensive damage and widespread power outages in eastern KS, Missouri, and Iowa.

Familiar script for Virginia on Sunday. Likely high-end severe outbreak to our west on this Sat, then strong shear aloft but less instability in Va on Sun. Less severe risk than South/TN Valley but still significant, gusty winds, tornadoes possible, more so east of Blue Ridge.

Spring is coming. That means severe weather season is fast approaching. Be prepared for the storms ahead. 

My friend John Hall has started Ahead of the Storm, LLC for those in the Va Bch area. That includes Gloucester, Middlesex & Mathews counties. 

For more info, send me a message to pass along!

This is the convective storm outlook for today and tomorrow.  Both days no severe storm are forecast although there will be areas with thunderstorms.

On the day of a severe weather event, watches and warnings are issued.

The Storm Prediction Center issues watches. Your local forecast office issues warnings.

What's the difference? Let's use bratwursts as an example!

(4/7)

The Storm Prediction Center issues severe weather outlooks for the current day and 7 days ahead.

The severe weather risk is quantified on a 1 - 5 scale, with a 5 being the highest risk.

As the number gets higher, the more likely severe storms are, and often the more intense they could be.

(3/7)

A severe thunderstorm is described as a storm that can potentially produce large hail, strong winds, flash flooding, and possibly even tornadoes. When you hear a severe thunderstorm watch or warning, you need to be prepared for more than just heavy rain and lightning.

Typically, a Severe T-storm or Tornado Watch will be issued about 2-6 hours before the storms develop and will remain in effect as they occur.  A Severe Thunderstorm or Tornado Warning gets issued when we see certain signatures on radar or have a storm report to issue it.  (2/3)

Well today 61 years ago I went through the Alaska Earthquake. I born and raised in Anchorage AK.

I was a few weeks old and in the crib when the earthquake hit. As the house shook, as the story goes, a mirror fell off the wall and smashed into my crib. My dad came to my rescue to save my from the shattered glass.

The earthquake killed dozens, as a nearby VA completely collapsed.
Hospitals were hard-hit in the San Fernando Earthquake, leading to the Hospital Safety Act of 1972. storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/2b52...

What they have not done is build new permanent veteran housing.

Learn more about how the earthquake drove veterans out of VA campus living by reading "The Land War," part 3 of our HOME OF THE BRAVE series: homeofthebrave.longlead.com/part/3/the-l...

üì∑: Francine Orr/Los Angeles Times via Getty

The 1971 earthquake marked the beginning of the end of housing on campus for veterans in LA.

In the decades since, lawmakers have built new medical facilities on the West LA VA campus and allowed outside interests, public and private alike, to use its grounds for their own benefit.

None of California‚Äôs VA facilities had been built to withstand a major spike on the Richter scale.

A year after the earthquake, the VA declared 30 of West LA campus‚Äô 236 buildings uninhabitable. It then ordered the nearly 1,500 veterans who lived on the campus to vacate within a month.

At least 46 of the more than 60 people who perished that day were veterans. All were receiving care at the Veterans Affairs hospital in the city‚Äôs northernmost neighborhood, Sylmar. 

Additional VA hospitals in the Valley also suffered serious damage.

Hi to a lot of new followers. If I haven't yet followed you, but I should, let me know. I'm an immunologist at CSU, interested in lung infections. I teach a lot! In my free time I ride my bike and take pictures of nature, mostly trains, storms, nebulae, and wildlife.

#weatherpicofday What an amazing storm this was. Taken near La Grange, WY on June 5th, 2009. Dave Lewison and I were just coming out for our annual chase trip and didn't make it in time to see the tornado that touched about 45 min prior. But a great way regardless to begin our 2009 chase trip.

My best two scud bombs. Both in Wyoming. Sadly, the one in the second image one happened before a really amazing landspout happened in Weld county less than 20 miles east of where I live (image 3 from Damen Winslow). 

I wanted to cry.

6/5/2009 in Dalton, NE, after we saw the Goshen County, WY, tornado 
6/10/2009 near Moscow, KS
6/11/2015 near Maitland, MO
5/24/2019 near Lubbock, TX. We were chasing before noon.
Hawk Springs EF2 Tornado Evolution (6/23/23)
The first #tornado I observed on June 12, 2017 near the Colorado/Wyoming border. This cell would go on to produce a stronger tornado near Carpenter, WY.  #WxSky

#OTD in 1945, F/L Harry Hardy DFC flew the last of his Pulverizers, RB389 'Pulverizer IV', for the first time. He took IV up for an air test and a mooch around the front lines before flying his 87th Op with 440 Sqn RCAF, leading an attack on V-1 storage sheds near Rotterdam.

1/2 #TyphoonTuesday

#OTD  in 1945 was "Black Sunday" for the Jagdwaffe, as the Allied Air Forces mounted major operations. The Allies claimed 238 victories against the Luftwaffe, which reported losing 176 aircraft. 

P-47s also shot down two Typhoons with the loss of a pilot, 247 Sqn's F/S Dudley Horn.

Accurately measuring earthquake size is one of the most important tasks in seismology, but is surprisingly difficult for small earthquakes. NSL PhD student Annie Patton used seismic coda - the extended ringing / shaking after direct phase arrivals - to measure sizes of small earthquakes in NV.
Weekly earthquake stats!Between Jan 15-Jan21, we located 81 earthquakes in NV! Our largest earthquake was a Ml3.91 located just outside Hawthorne.

Introducing the weekly earthquake roundup! Overall, a quieter week but had one moderate size event (Ml 3.58) in south central NV late on Saturday night and we‚Äôre still clocking aftershocks from the Parker Butte 5.7 in December.

Rounding up the top three is an earthquake that wasn‚Äôt even in California! However, the 12/9/24 M5.7 Parker Butte, NV earthquake was the largest earthquake in the contiguous U.S. in 2024, produced minor surface rupture, & was felt widely in CA, so it gets a shout out in this earthquake roundup. 3/7
